feed.title: Lareau Lab
feed.subtitle: The Lareau Laboratory for Computational and Systems Immunology is in the csBio Program at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, New York, NY.

entry.title: First protein design paper online!
entry.content: The lab’s first paper on de novo protein design is out on bioRxiv. We screened over 1,500 new proteins for efficacy in binding and CAR T efficacy, discovering principles that inform how to make effective CAR T cells for a variety of surface antigens. Congrats to Arthur, Hoyin, Betty, Benan, Abi, and Laura for leading the lab in a new direction!
entry.summary: The lab’s first paper on de novo protein design is out on bioRxiv. We screened over 1,500 new proteins for efficacy in binding and CAR T efficacy, discovering principles that inform how to make effective CAR T cells for a variety of surface antigens. Congrats to Arthur, Hoyin, Betty, Benan, Abi, and Laura for leading the lab in a new direction!

entry.title: New papers online!
entry.content: Several papers from our collaborative projects are now online! Led by the Alex Gitlin lab, new work provides a thorough mechanistic characterization of VEXAS Syndrome. In a shared effort with Payam Gammage and Ed Reznik, we help characterize functionally dominant hotspot mutations in mitochondrial ribosomal RNA. Finally, in a collaboration with Robbie Majzner’s group at Dana Farber, we defined how SLP-76 can be engineered to improve T cell fitness and antigen sensitivity. Thanks to Benan and Hoyin for helping with these collaborative efforts!
entry.summary: Several papers from our collaborative projects are now online! Led by the Alex Gitlin lab, new work provides a thorough mechanistic characterization of VEXAS Syndrome. In a shared effort with Payam Gammage and Ed Reznik, we help characterize functionally dominant hotspot mutations in mitochondrial ribosomal RNA. Finally, in a collaboration with Robbie Majzner’s group at Dana Farber, we defined how SLP-76 can be engineered to improve T cell fitness and antigen sensitivity. Thanks to Benan and Hoyin for helping with these collaborative efforts!

entry.title: NYC Marathon!
entry.content: Cole and Caleb complete the New York City Marathon! Thanks to the lab for coming out in support and for the generous donations to Fred’s Team.
entry.summary: Cole and Caleb complete the New York City Marathon! Thanks to the lab for coming out in support and for the generous donations to Fred’s Team.

entry.title: National Academy of Medicine Catalyst
entry.content: The lab is awarded a Catalyst prize from the National Academy of Medicine for our continued work in defining the human virome. Thank you NAM for believing in our vision and supporting our work!
entry.summary: The lab is awarded a Catalyst prize from the National Academy of Medicine for our continued work in defining the human virome. Thank you NAM for believing in our vision and supporting our work!

entry.title: Revised Logan Preprint
entry.content: The lab collaborates in the latest generation of the Logan Project, including a heavily revised preprint. Try it out for yourself using the LoganSearch webtool.
entry.summary: The lab collaborates in the latest generation of the Logan Project, including a heavily revised preprint. Try it out for yourself using the LoganSearch webtool.

entry.title: New grant support!
entry.content: The lab receives an Notice of Award from the National Cancer Institute’s IMAT Program for advanced development of nucleic acid cytometry!
entry.summary: The lab receives an Notice of Award from the National Cancer Institute’s IMAT Program for advanced development of nucleic acid cytometry!

entry.title: 100 mile run!
entry.content: Paul, Cole and Caleb conquer the Badger 101.1 mile trail race! Check out these exhausted but ecstatic finishers!!.
entry.summary: Paul, Cole and Caleb conquer the Badger 101.1 mile trail race! Check out these exhausted but ecstatic finishers!!.

entry.title: New papers online!
entry.content: A flurry of papers are now out this month! Out now in PNAS, our characterization of purifying selection in a mtDNA synonymous allele is published. Check out the fun backstory here. Next, a preprint with the Dhindsa Lab @BCM studying Epstein-Barr virus using population sequencing is out on bioRxiv. Finally, a collaboration with the Satpathy lab is available on bioRxiv now! Congratulations to Sherry, Erin, Jacob, Benan, Meghana, Thahmina, and Laura for their huge contributions to these works spanning mitochondrial genetics, cancer biology, and viral persistence!
entry.summary: A flurry of papers are now out this month! Out now in PNAS, our characterization of purifying selection in a mtDNA synonymous allele is published. Check out the fun backstory here. Next, a preprint with the Dhindsa Lab @BCM studying Epstein-Barr virus using population sequencing is out on bioRxiv. Finally, a collaboration with the Satpathy lab is available on bioRxiv now! Congratulations to Sherry, Erin, Jacob, Benan, Meghana, Thahmina, and Laura for their huge contributions to these works spanning mitochondrial genetics, cancer biology, and viral persistence!

entry.title: Cornell Protein Science Symposium!
entry.content: Many members of the lab travel to Cornell @ Ithaca for the Protein Science Symposium! Congratulations to Laura for being selected to give a talk on exciting new proteo-genomics work coming from the lab!
entry.summary: Many members of the lab travel to Cornell @ Ithaca for the Protein Science Symposium! Congratulations to Laura for being selected to give a talk on exciting new proteo-genomics work coming from the lab!

entry.title: High school STEM night!
entry.content: The lab attends the NYSCI Teen & STEM night! Located at the New York Hall of Science, the STEM career night brought in >500 local high school students to learn more about careers in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. Our lab represented MSKCC, and our team shared about how AI enables new careers and potentially new cancer therapies! Thanks to Betty, Arthur, Benan, Zeyu, and Hoyin for spending their Friday night with a bunch of high schoolers!
